title: Olivia Dean Wins Big at Brit Awards Amid Chaotic, Oft-Bleeped Show
full_text: Feb 28, 2026 5:40pm PT Olivia Dean Wins Big at Brit Awards Amid Chaotic, Oft-Bleeped Show By Mark Sutherland Plus Icon Mark Sutherland Latest Olivia Dean Wins Big at Brit Awards Amid Chaotic, Oft-Bleeped Show 7 hours ago Where Fans Dive in: Why YouTube Is the Epicentre of Culture for Music and Sports 3 months ago Raye and Sonyâ€™s Jon Platt Speak Out for Songwriters at Ivors Academy Honours Ceremony 5 months ago See All (Photo by Karwai Tang/WireImage) In the run-up to the 2026 Brit Awards being staged outside of London for the first time ever, a local Manchester train station excitedly changed its name, from Deansgate to Olivia Deansgate. But the big question going into British musicâ€™s biggest awards ceremony was, would the awards themselves need a similar name change? Well, letâ€™s just call them the Olivias, shall we? Dean â€“ who, with her Grammy win for Best New Artist has become a focal point for the British music resurgence â€“ picked up four of the five awards she was up for: Album of the Year, Artist of the Year, Pop Act and a share of Song of the Year for her duet with Sam Fender on â€œRein Me In.â€ She also pulled off one of the performances of the night with a delightfully breezy â€œMan I Need,â€ embodying her old school mainstream appeal. Popular on Variety Related Stories Series Creators Push Back as the Industry Gets â€˜Nervousâ€™ About Important Stories and Female Perspective: â€˜The Content Might Be Different Enough to Actually Make a Differenceâ€™ 'Bridgerton' Stars Hannah Dodd, Masali Baduza and Victor Alli on Francesca's Unlikely Romance and That Shocking Death And, while Charli xcx, Raye and Harry Styles have similarly dominated Britainâ€™s leading awards ceremony in recent years, Deanâ€™s success was all the more meaningful because this was no walkover. She faced meaningful opposition from equally worthy potential winners in every category, with genuine global U.K. success stories suddenly seemingly everywhere. Perhaps thatâ€™s why her multiple tearful acceptance speeches all seemed charmingly overwhelmed to the point of befuddlement, barely mustering a quote of note between them (â€œThis album is just about love, and loving each other in a world that feels loveless right now,â€ was about as headline-grabbing as it got). No matter: plenty of other people stepped up on that front. This was a vintage Brits, packed full of talking points, incidents and a general air of unpredictability in a way we havenâ€™t seen since the peak Britpop era in the mid-â€˜90s. Returning superstar Harry Styles kicked things off with a bang via a bravura performance of â€œApertureâ€ from his hotly anticipated â€œKiss All the Time, Disco Occasionallyâ€ album, which comes out this Friday. Raye went full James Bond theme with a brassy combo of â€œWhere Is My Husband?â€ and â€œNightingale Lane.â€ And Wolf Alice marked their transition from plucky indie types to full-on rock stars with a stunning acoustic version of â€œThe Sofa,â€ set in a living room, that ended with frontwoman Ellie Rowsell lifted high by her backing dancers. The band also picked up Group of the Year, with Rowsell speaking up for better support for grassroots venues and artists themselves, declaring: â€œThis shouldnâ€™t feel like a golden ticket, but a viable career decision.â€ In recent years, the Brits have relied heavily on international artists to provide the star power, but overall this yearâ€™s contingent were rather more mundane. An exception was International Artist of the Year winner RosalÃ­a, who provided some edge with a dramatic take on â€œBerghainâ€ that featured an attention-grabbing appearance from BjÃ¶rk; RosalÃ­a also did a surprisingly good Liam Gallagher impression in a chat with host Jack Whitehall. But Alex Warrenâ€™s performance of â€œOrdinaryâ€ lived up to its name, despite the presence of James Blunt on piano (â€œJames Blunt without a microphone â€“ everyoneâ€™s a winner,â€ quipped Whitehall); the KPop Demon Hunters performance was pre-recorded so failed to connect in the room; Sombrâ€™s obviously staged altercation with a pretend-stage-invader barely registered in a cynical industry section that has seen plenty of actual Brits stage invasions over the years. More authentic controversy came from Whitehall in trademark near-the-knuckle form, with his jokes about the Epstein files being censored from the live broadcast (notably â€œI think that I saw Peter Mandelson on the guest list,â€ referencing the former ambassador to the U.S. who was arrested in connection with the files). He also goaded Happy Mondays legends Shaun Ryder and Bez into making slanderous remarks about Paddington Bear, while Geese bassist Max Bassin declared, â€œFree Palestine, fuck ICEâ€ as he picked up the International Group of the Year award, and Noel Gallagher concluded his Best Songwriter acceptance speech with â€œUp the fucking Bluesâ€ â€” a Manchester City soccer reference that brought forth an avalanche of boos (with half of Manchester supporting the other Manchester team, United). But, really, tonight was about British music regaining its confidence to the point where you wondered if some of those international slots might better have gone to U.K. stars. Breakthrough Artist winner Lola Young performed â€œMessyâ€ at last yearâ€™s ceremony, but surely deserved a return, while Lily Allen â€“ maker of â€œWest End Girl,â€ the most talked-about album of the year and one of the best â€“ sadly did not perform, despite rumors she was in negotiations for a slot. This embarrassment of riches not only elevated the TV spectacle, but also the atmosphere in the Co-op Live Arena (which has successfully bounced back from its disastrous opening in 2024).
